comment._content: Is there a picture of Ducktown today? The last time we rode through that area it seemed that most of that land had been reclaimed, and looked nothing like this picture.

comment.author: 49675886@N07
comment._content:
This is the caption that Marion Post Walcott included with her photo from 1939 but the actual damage to the vegetation occurred in the late 1800's. The smelting technology of that time did not allow the sulfur dioxide generated by the heating of the ore to be captured. By 1909 the mining companies developed new practices which let them recover the sulfur dioxide and use it in the manufacture of sulfuric acid. 

Reclamation in the Basin began in the 1930's with varying degrees of success initially.  By the 1970's new techniques were developed and today most of the Basin has been revegetated.

comment.author: 80297647@N00
comment._content: Not really. The Basin remained denuded until the acid plant and mining operation went out of business in the late '80's. I grew up there, and it looked just like this till I was out of college in the '80's.

comment.author: 107200784@N07
comment._content: I rode thru there yesterday, 10/13/2013.  The Copper Basin is now very green, and the forest is coming back.  It's going to take generations for the trees to mature, however.  Just don't drink the water.
